                    });                 });             }          } })();  The math confronting the Yankees on Monday was simple. They arrived at Yankee Stadium two weeks from the trade deadline, eight and a half games back in the American League East, and hosting first-place Baltimore for four games.If the Yankees were going to get into or out of the playoff race for good, there was no time like the present.\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s where we\xe2\x80\x99re at,\xe2\x80\x9d catcher Brian McCann said after the Yankees took a first step in the right direction with a 2-1 victory over the Orioles. \xe2\x80\x9cA little over two months of baseball left and we\xe2\x80\x99ve got to start winning.\xe2\x80\x9dThe Yankees were buoyed by a confluence of rare events: Ivan Nova escaping trouble at every turn, Alex Rodriguez hitting his first home run in a month, and Aroldis Chapman drawing oohs and aahs, shattering a bat and throwing fastballs that registered at 105 miles per hour. Continue reading the main story        Advertisement  Continue reading the main story      Those events helped prop up an offense that has scored just 10 runs in four games since the All-Star break, and pushed the decisive marker across when Carlos Beltran sharply executed a hit-and-run single in the third inning that sent Brett Gardner to third, from where he scored on a sacrifice fly by McCann on the next at-bat.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Before the game, Manager Joe Girardi did his best to avoid putting too much weight on this series, waving away a question about whether the Yankees needed to sweep it, or at least win three of four to consider themselves contenders.\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m worried about winning tonight,\xe2\x80\x9d Girardi said. \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t ever put numbers on things, because I think it can put limitations on what you do. So we need to win tonight, and then we\xe2\x80\x99ll worry about tomorrow.\xe2\x80\x9dWith the Yankees\xe2\x80\x99 other struggling slugger, Mark Teixeira, out at least until Wednesday after being hit by a pitch on the foot Saturday, Rodriguez drove a 94-m.p.h. fastball from Kevin Gausman deep to left.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Before afternoon showers came and wiped out batting practice, Rodriguez had worked on a drill that the former hitting coach Kevin Long favored. A hitting screen was placed across home plate, bisecting it. Rodriguez then choked up on the bat as balls were tossed to him, refining a technique that would prevent him from getting jammed.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  The work, brief as it was, seemed to have had a desired effect.\xe2\x80\x9cMechanics have been a humongous struggle for me all year,\xe2\x80\x9d Rodriguez said. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s been hard for me to get the ball in the air consistently.\xe2\x80\x9d Newsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Sports Newsletter Get the big sports news, highlights and analysis from Times journalists, with distinctive takes on games and some behind-the-scenes surprises, delivered to your inbox every week. Privacy Policy     He added: \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve been really bad this year. I\xe2\x80\x99ve been working my butt off, and I haven\xe2\x80\x99t been able to figure it out. The last five or six days, working hard with Alan and Marcus, I\xe2\x80\x99m getting to see the light at the end of the tunnel.\xe2\x80\x9d Alan Cockrell and Marcus Thames are the Yankees hitting coaches.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  There was nothing pedestrian about Rodriguez\xe2\x80\x99s home run, his ninth this season, which brought his career total to 696. Rodriguez admired its flight into the bleachers, a worthy way for him to mark the end of a drought that had lasted one month, since he homered against Minnesota\xe2\x80\x99s Ricky Nolasco on June 18.It had also been some time since Rodriguez had celebrated a home run at Yankee Stadium, his last one coming more than three months ago, on April 17, against Seattle\xe2\x80\x99s Hisashi Iwakuma.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Nova, who shut out the Orioles for six innings last month before collapsing in the seventh, had his share of unsteady moments. He escaped the first inning when Pedro Alvarez popped out with the bases loaded. Center fielder Jacoby Ellsbury had to run down two hard-hit balls by Matt Wieters and Ryan Flaherty, and third baseman Chase Headley neatly gloved a smash by Jonathan Schoop.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Yet other than allowing a leadoff homer by Schoop in the third, Nova was unscathed. Once he gained better command of his sinker and curveball, keeping them down, he retired the final seven batters he faced.It was hard to ask for more against the team that leads baseball with 142 home runs, even if the Orioles were without first baseman Chris Davis, who was ill.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  \xe2\x80\x9cThe big thing when you face a club like this is you have to make your pitches, because if you don\xe2\x80\x99t, a lot of them are going to leave the ballpark,\xe2\x80\x9d Girardi said before the game. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd you can\xe2\x80\x99t give them extra outs. You can recover from a solo home run. It\xe2\x80\x99s hard to recover from two and three-run home runs.\xe2\x80\x9dNova, who is 7-5 with a 4.92 E.R.A., did not look like the same pitcher who two weeks ago appeared to be trying to save his spot in the rotation.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  \xe2\x80\x9cHe was wildly effective, a little bit,\xe2\x80\x9d Orioles Manager Buck Showalter said. \xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s got a lot of two-seam movement, he\xe2\x80\x99s one of the top ground-ball throwers in baseball. You look out there at the E.R.A. and stuff \xe2\x80\x94 you wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t think that watching him tonight.\xe2\x80\x9dThe Yankees, like the Orioles, had bountiful opportunities early: Beltran rocketed a double to the right-center gap and Starlin Castro sliced one into the right-field corner, but neither scored.After Schoop\xe2\x80\x99s home run tied the score, McCann brought Gardner sliding home on a fly ball that center fielder Adam Jones caught but skipped too late on the throw. It gave the Yankees a lead and a chance to look forward to the next day.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  \xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s all we can do at this point because of all the noise around,\xe2\x80\x9d Girardi said. \xe2\x80\x9cI think you just have to focus on tomorrow.\xe2\x80\x9d  A version of this article appears in print on July 19, 2016, on Page B9 of the New York edition with the headline: Rodriguez Homers, and Nova Helps Yankees Edge First-Place Orioles. You try to get them out on three pitches, and I feel like that\xe2\x80\x99s the way I need to be when I\xe2\x80\x99m starting, too.\xe2\x80\x9dWhatever lessons Eovaldi learned in his brief sabbatical in the bullpen were put to good use Tuesday night when he returned to the rotation and shut out the Baltimore Orioles into the sixth inning of a 7-1 victory at Yankee Stadium.While Eovaldi was holding the Orioles in check, Starlin Castro did the heavy lifting for the Yankees\xe2\x80\x99 offense by driving in four runs with a home run and double, and reliever Anthony Swarzak and first baseman Rob Refsnyder helped defuse a dangerous threat in the sixth. Continue reading the main story        Advertisement  Continue reading the main story      The win, the Yankees\xe2\x80\x99 third in a row, pushed them over .500 for the first time since June 25 and drew them six and a half games behind the first-place Orioles in the American League East.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  With two more games left here against the Orioles, the victory also gave a boost to the players\xe2\x80\x99 hopes of convincing management that they are viable playoff contenders so that the Yankees do not trade Carlos Beltran, Aroldis Chapman or other veterans for prospects as the Aug. 1 nonwaiver trade deadline nears.\xe2\x80\x9cThe feeling in this clubhouse is really good right now,\xe2\x80\x9d Swarzak said. \xe2\x80\x9cNobody in this room believes we can\xe2\x80\x99t do it.\xe2\x80\x9d Photo       Nathan Eovaldi, who had recently been in the bullpen, started and held the Orioles to one run in five and a third innings.  Credit             Frank Franklin Ii/Associated Press           Swarzak, a 30-year-old right-hander who is with his third team in three years, was handed his highest-leverage opportunity this season \xe2\x80\x94 entering the game with the bases loaded, one out and the major leagues\xe2\x80\x99 leading home run hitter, Mark Trumbo, at the plate as the Yankees clung to a 3-1 lead in the sixth inning.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  \xe2\x80\x9cAnytime you\xe2\x80\x99ve got a guy that\xe2\x80\x99s hot and can hit the ball over the fence, if you try to nitpick with him you\xe2\x80\x99re going to get yourself in trouble,\xe2\x80\x9d Swarzak said. \xe2\x80\x9cYou just want to go at him with your best stuff and challenge him.\xe2\x80\x9d  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Swarzak threw a slider over the outside edge for a called strike. Trumbo, who has 28 home runs, hit the next pitch high into foul territory down the right-field line.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Refsnyder, who had never played first base until May, caught the ball with his back to the plate, and then adeptly turned and bounced an accurate throw home that kept Adam Jones anchored at third.\xe2\x80\x9cIf I would have been hesitant, maybe he would have gone,\xe2\x80\x9d Refsnyder said. \xe2\x80\x9cYou just kind of think through all those things before the pitch. I\xe2\x80\x99ve been trying to work through all those plays so they\xe2\x80\x99re kind of reactionary.\xe2\x80\x9dEarlier, Refsnyder had walked, stolen second and scored on Jacoby Ellsbury\xe2\x80\x99s single, pushing the Yankees\xe2\x80\x99 lead to 3-0 in the fifth. But that was not Ellsbury\xe2\x80\x99s singular accomplishment Tuesday: It came when he reached base in the first on catcher\xe2\x80\x99s interference, his swing clipping the glove of catcher Caleb Joseph.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  It was the ninth time this season that Ellsbury has reached on catcher\xe2\x80\x99s interference, surpassing Roberto Kelly for the single-season record.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Castro, who had given the Yankees a 2-0 lead with a blistering two-run homer in the second \xe2\x80\x94 Statcast recorded its exit velocity at 110.4 miles per hour, the second fastest in baseball this season \xe2\x80\x94 provided a cushion after Swarzak\xe2\x80\x99s escape. Betances had been warming up in the seventh. ', 'baltimore.cbslocal.com'), ('Baltimore Orioles: The Offensive Switch is \\u2026 Off', 'Jul 18, 2016; Bronx, NY, USA; Baltimore Orioles starting pitcher Kevin Gausman (39) reacts walking to the dugout against the New York Yankees during the seventh inning at Yankee Stadium. Mandatory Credit: Adam Hunger-USA TODAY SportsThe Baltimore Orioles, in spite of their well-known starting pitching woes, have had recent problems that are actually worse on the offensives side of the game.It is almost as if the offensive switch for the team has somehow slipped into the \xe2\x80\x9coff\xe2\x80\x9d position. It is a curious thing to see, having so often seen just the opposite.We have known all along that this was going to be a streaky team. That is the nature of a squad that is built upon power, possessing also the proclivity to strike out quite a bit.We knew also that good pitching was going to some days put quite a damper on the fire of the O\xe2\x80\x99s powerful lineup. Not to take anything away from the five pitchers of the Rays and Yankees that the Birds have seen since the ASG break, that have not been that incredible. Baltimore is simply not hitting the baseball.The big concern (that is a reality) is that the Orioles are in greatest peril because of pitching rotation woes. But even if the O\xe2\x80\x99s traded away every talent in the franchise\xe2\x80\x99s minor leagues to secure, say, the two best starters available before the trade deadline, it will not matter if the offense is going to score only 10 runs per five games.Consider some of these other statistics: Since the break, the Orioles have gone 31-for-161 at the plate. That is an average of .193. \xc2\xa0More from Baltimore Orioles5/12 - Baltimore Orioles vs. Kansas City Royals: 4 things to watch5/11 - Baltimore Orioles sign first baseman/outfielder Adam Walker5/11 - Baltimore Orioles: Late-inning bullpen options in Minor Leagues5/11 - Baltimore Orioles: Could Logan Verrett be a starter?5/9 - Baltimore Orioles\xe2\x80\x99 Zach Britton to miss 45-60 days with forearm injuryWorse than that is the average with runners in scoring position. There have only been 24 such situations in these five games. And the Orioles are 2-for-24 for an average of .083.\xc2\xa0 This is not going to work on any level.With the lead down now to a half-game over Papi and Lilliputians, this needs to turn around. And it will. The Orioles have hit in the past and they will hit in the future. The challenge for the remaining season is to hit and pitch well enough to get into the playoffs, hoping also that October will be one of those seasons when the offense is collectively hitting ball. ', 'thebaltimorewire.com'), ('Baltimore Orioles: Getting NY back on track - Birds Watcher', 'The Baltimore Orioles are seemingly helping New York up a bit if the first two games of four mean anything.While it\xe2\x80\x99s certainly not intentional, the Baltimore Orioles have in essence offered a glimmer of hope to their rivals in the Bronx in the first two games of four this week. On Sunday night when NY played Boston, ESPN\xe2\x80\x99s crew was very careful to say that decisions were being made as they spoke as to whether New York was going to buy or sell at the deadline. New York of course won that game, and they\xe2\x80\x99ve taken the first two from the first place O\xe2\x80\x99s.So again, it\xe2\x80\x99s not as if the Birds are trying to help New York. But if the word on the street happened to be that NY was going to sell, you have to wonder if that isn\xe2\x80\x99t starting to change. If they look at the standings and see that they\xe2\x80\x99re now only 6.5 games out of first\xe2\x80\xa6you never know, right? And that\xe2\x80\x99s all the Orioles really need; a New York team that suddenly becomes an underdog story and captures the attention of the nation as they come out of nowhere to get to the postseason.Vance Worley was ineffective as a starter last night, although it\xe2\x80\x99s tough to win when you only put up one run as a team. Worley\xe2\x80\x99s line: 4.1 IP, 3 H, 3 R, 4 BB, 3 K. He gave up a two-run homer to Castro in the second, and he was also responsible for the run that scored in the fifth on Ellsbury\xe2\x80\x99s RBI-single.\xc2\xa0Live Feed vance worleyBaltimore Orioles interested in Vance Worley reunion The Baltimore WireDetroit Tigers: Recently-Released Players Worth Taking a Flier on Motor City BengalsWashington Nationals: Vance Worley Could Provide Much Needed Rotation Depth District on DeckChicago Cubs: Potential suitors for vacant rotation spots Cubbies CribDetroit Tigers: Five Non-Tendered Players Who Are Potential Fits Motor City BengalsBaltimore Orioles Acquire Former Rule Five Pick Logan Verrett The Baltimore WireThe O\xe2\x80\x99s tried to put up somewhat of a fight when Rickard\xe2\x80\x99s RBI-double cut it to 3-1 in the sixth. However that rally was over in a New York minute. Castro smacked a two-RBI double in the last of the inning, and Headley a two-run homer in the last of the eighth.So the question is whether or not New York still views themselves as sellers as the deadline aproaches. One would hope that no team would be compulsive enough to allow a couple of games to influence their thinking. Odds are the O\xe2\x80\x99s are just going through a short skid, and at some point will break back out the bats and move forward. However\xe2\x80\xa6\xc2\xa0More from Editorials/Analysis2/20 - Baltimore Orioles: Previewing the 2017 Season2/18 - Baltimore Orioles: How safe is Joey Rickard\xe2\x80\x99s spot on the roster?2/15 - Baltimore Orioles: Time to snap up Jorge De La Rosa?2/13 - Baltimore Orioles: Nevada Sportsbooks Betting on a 2017 Decline1/30 - Baltimore Orioles: Craig Breslow is an intriguing name for the Orioles to consider\xe2\x80\xa6New York is still New York. Over the years they\xe2\x80\x99ve been very good at just living on a prayer and having that work out well for them. If you\xe2\x80\x99re the O\xe2\x80\x99s, you\xe2\x80\x99re wanting to shut the door on them. But through two games that door has slowly begun to inch back open. And it\xe2\x80\x99s up to them to close it up again.\xc2\xa0Next: Baltimore Orioles: Offense a problem in the second half?The series will continue this evening in the Bronx.\xc2\xa0Yovani Gallardo will try to be the Orioles\xe2\x80\x99 stopper, and he\xe2\x80\x99ll be opposed by NY\xe2\x80\x99s\xc2\xa0Michael Pineda. Game time is set for just after 7 PM. ', 'birdswatcher.com'), ('Orioles Prospects: A glance at several unknown superstars ...', ' Much has been made about the talent drought in the current state of the Orioles system, and rightfully so. As we sit in the middle of the 2016 season, the lack of top prospects within the Birds organization is more than evident.     It dominates the O\xe2\x80\x99s minor-league storylines and tends to blind views of favorable storylines that pop up every night.  Is the farm system in Baltimore as rich as its ever been? Hardly. But at the end of the day, that simple fact sets up \xe2\x80\x9cdiamond in the rough\xe2\x80\x9d situations throughout the organization - opportunities for young unknowns to burst onto the scene.  And thus far in 2016, plenty of firepower has emerged for at-least a second look.     Aderlin Rodriguez - Frederick When the Mets released Rodriguez at the end of last season, they were likely fairly convinced that the end of his road would be near. From 2012-2014, he was a middle-of-the-pack hitter with power potential and errors aplenty at the corner infield slots. Bottom line, he had appeared to be maxed out.     But don\xe2\x80\x99t tell that to the 2016 version of Aderlin Rodriguez. Whatever he\xe2\x80\x99s done since entering the Orioles organization, it\xe2\x80\x99s been working. Over 89 games with Frederick, Rodriguez is hitting .314 with a .911 OPS.  He\xe2\x80\x99s combined for 41 extra-base hits, including 18 doubles and 17 round-trippers. His strikeout rate is slightly high at 23-percent, but in the grand totality of his game, that\xe2\x80\x99s not a terrible concern.     He\xe2\x80\x99s primarily locking down first base for Frederick, but he\xe2\x80\x99s played 90 innings at the hot corner where he has plenty of experience from his time with the Mets.  And while the makeup of the Orioles system doesn\xe2\x80\x99t exactly bode well for his future with the Orioles, certainly don\xe2\x80\x99t count the 24-year-old out of future trade discussions.  Cole Billingsley - Aberdeen It\xe2\x80\x99s a bit odd to talk about a successful outfielder in the Orioles system, isn\xe2\x80\x99t it? Luckily, Billingsley is proving that trends are meant to be broken ... well, at-least through the first 73 at-bats of his first steps in pro ball.     The former South Alabama standout is crushing opposing pitching this season, starting with a .329/.417/.521 trio. Drafted in the 16th round last month, the 22-year-old Ironbird is already finding a way to make it work in the pros.  Sure, it\xe2\x80\x99s early and it\xe2\x80\x99s short-season single A baseball, but why not celebrate a non-catcher/first baseman doing big things at the dish in the system?  What\xe2\x80\x99s encouraging about Billingsley is the sheer potential that could lie ahead. He hit .302 in 2013 before sitting out his entire sophomore season as a medical redshirt. In 2015, he exploded with a .345 average, .437 OBP and 30 stolen bases (which he does have three of in his first 20 games in Aberdeen).  If he follows the path he\xe2\x80\x99s been sprinting since graduating high-school, the former Team USA 16U star might just find his way onto 2017\xe2\x80\x99s top minor-league prospect watch list.  Yermin Mercedes - Delmarva Mercedes is a catcher, which might put him in a difficult position to climb up the ladder moving forward. However, his 2016 numbers are simply too impressive to ignore   - perhaps for other teams around the league.     After spending 2011-2013 in the Dominican Summer League, Mercedes emerged onto the scene last season with a very respectable year in Delmarva. He hit .272 with eight home runs in 64 games, working a total .456 slugging percentage. Not bad, but not nearly close to the totals he\xe2\x80\x99s collected this campaign.  Through 82 games, Mercedes is absolutely crushing the baseball with a .352 average and .558 slugging percentage. He\xe2\x80\x99s getting on base 40 percent of the time as a staple of the middle of Delmarva\xe2\x80\x99s lineup, hitting 11 home runs with 53 RBI in the process.  His .390 average against left-handers is just one more reason why he\xe2\x80\x99s become the clear contender for Orioles minor-leaguer of the year. And depending on what he looks like behind the dish, Mercedes could eventually emerge as a premier prize in a future trade situation.  Next Wednesday, we\xe2\x80\x99ll go over three surprise arms toeing the rubber in the 2016 Orioles system.   ', 'www.camdenchat.com')]

                    });                 });             }          } })();  Baseball players engage in all sorts of rituals to maintain their gloves, pounding the hardened spots with customized tools or using a variety of oils to soften them. Although it seems easy, closing a glove around a baseball is sometimes harder than it looks.Case in point: Thursday afternoon\xe2\x80\x99s game at Yankee Stadium. On three occasions, Yankees infielders failed to secure a ball, and each time, the defensive miscue led to a run. As a result, the Yankees were unable to complete a four-game sweep of the Baltimore Orioles, falling by 4-1.C. C. Sabathia pitched well on his 36th birthday, but he was foiled by soft base hits. Sabathia tossed six and two-thirds innings, allowing two runs in the first inning and two more in the seventh.\xe2\x80\x9cI thought he gave us a gritty performance today \xe2\x80\x94 it\xe2\x80\x99s unfortunate,\xe2\x80\x9d Manager Joe Girardi said. \xe2\x80\x9cHe didn\xe2\x80\x99t give up a lot of hard-hit balls, and you look up and there\xe2\x80\x99s four runs on the board.\xe2\x80\x9d Continue reading the main story        Advertisement  Continue reading the main story      The Orioles\xe2\x80\x99 initial hit came when Yankees shortstop Didi Gregorius did not cleanly scoop a slow roller off the bat of Jonathon Schoop in the first inning. The Orioles eventually loaded the bases for J. J. Hardy, who hit a sharp line drive that deflected off the top of Gregorius\xe2\x80\x99s mitt and fell into left field, bringing home two runs.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Sabathia allowed only one hit over his next five innings before allowing back-to-back one-out singles in the seventh. That brought up Schoop again, and he doubled to right, easily scoring Caleb Joseph. Right fielder Carlos Beltran fired the ball to Mark Teixeira at first base as Julio Borbon rounded third, but Teixeira dropped the throw, and Borbon scored.Despite having his bullpen ready, Girardi chose to stay with Sabathia in the seventh. After the game, Girardi repeatedly defended his decision, pointing to Sabathia\xe2\x80\x99s previous success against Schoop, who was 3 for 13 until that point against him.\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re probably extremely frustrated, because when you\xe2\x80\x99re not giving up hard contact, you\xe2\x80\x99re making good pitches, and it\xe2\x80\x99s frustrating for him and for us that they\xe2\x80\x99re turning into base hits,\xe2\x80\x9d Girardi said, adding about the Schoop at-bat, \xe2\x80\x9cYou look at the base hit, it wasn\xe2\x80\x99t hit hard, it was just extremely well placed.\xe2\x80\x9d Newsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Sports Newsletter Get the big sports news, highlights and analysis from Times journalists, with distinctive takes on games and some behind-the-scenes surprises, delivered to your inbox every week. Privacy Policy     Just as precise as the Orioles\xe2\x80\x99 hits was the work of starter Chris Tillman, whose record improved to 14-2.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Tillman allowed one run on four hits over seven innings, and the relievers who followed him allowed only one other hit. Over all, the Yankees sluggers Beltran, Brian McCann, Teixeira and Alex Rodriguez, who was moved down to seventh in the order, were hitless in a combined 14 at-bats.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  \xe2\x80\x9cTillman was almost unhittable,\xe2\x80\x9d Teixeira said.The Orioles\xe2\x80\x99 victory brought a bit of calm after a negative start to the series. In addition to dropping the first three games against the Yankees, the Orioles fell out of first place in the American League East, passed by the Boston Red Sox. On Wednesday, Manager Buck Showalter, first baseman Chris Davis and third baseman Manny Machado were absent from the game because of flulike symptoms that have spread through the Orioles\xe2\x80\x99 clubhouse.The bug reportedly originated at the All-Star Game in San Diego last week, infecting catcher Matt Wieters and reliever Zach Britton. Despite his sparkling record, Tillman was not selected as an All-Star, but he is probably happy to be in good health.Showalter did not hold his customary pregame news conference with reporters on Thursday, but he was in the dugout to manage the game.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Orioles players said they had been washing their hands more thoroughly and using hand sanitizer to prevent the illness from spreading further.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Before Thursday\xe2\x80\x99s loss, the Yankees showed signs of mounting a charge up the standings after entering the series eight and a half games out of first place in the A.L. East. They shaved their deficit slightly, although three teams remain ahead of them in the division standings.\xe2\x80\x9cI think you have to look at it as you took three of four from a good Baltimore team, and you have to move on,\xe2\x80\x9d Girardi said.INSIDE PITCHThe Yankees optioned NICK GOODY to Class AAA Scranton/Wilkes-Barre and recalled CHAD GREEN, who pitched two and a third scoreless innings in relief Thursday. \xe2\x80\xa6 CHASE HEADLEY pinch-hit in the eighth inning after missing Wednesday\xe2\x80\x99s game for personal reasons. Headley said after the game that his son, Colt, 4, had an operation over the All-Star break last week and had recently had complications. On Wednesday, Headley took his son back to the hospital for another procedure, and Headley said Thursday that Colt was \xe2\x80\x9cdoing a lot better.\xe2\x80\x9d  A version of this article appears in print on July 22, 2016, on Page B11 of the New York edition with the headline: Little Things Hurt Yankees, Who Can\xe2\x80\x99t Complete Sweep of Orioles. Waiting for Another Team to Act JULY 19, 2016                       ', 'www.nytimes.com'), ('The Baltimore Wire: Baltimore Orioles and a Roster in Flux', 'Jul 21, 2016; Bronx, NY, USA; Baltimore Orioles catcher Caleb Joseph (36) and center fielder Julio Borbon (29) score during the seventh inning against the New York Yankees at Yankee Stadium. Mandatory Credit: Anthony Gruppuso-USA TODAY SportsThe Baltimore Orioles\xe2\x80\x99 roster is currently in flux, as they wait for Darren O\xe2\x80\x99Day to come back from the disabled list, which could come as soon as this weekend.Then, they will wait for Hyun Soo Kim to come back, and that should happen at the end of the 15-day period.The question then becomes, should that be the only changes?Let\xe2\x80\x99s assume for this that no trades are made, and that Dylan Bundy and Vance Worley remain in the rotation.That would mean the bullpen would consist of Zach Britton, who picked up save 30 against the Yankees on Thursday afternoon, Brad Brach, O\xe2\x80\x99Day, Mychal Givens, Chaz Roe, Donnie Hart, Ubaldo Jimenez, Odrisamer Despaigne.\xc2\xa0 Someone there will have to go.My pick is Ubaldo, but I\xe2\x80\x99m not sure that the team has the stones to do that. I think Hart\xe2\x80\x99s ability to get out lefties is valuable on this team, and he has pitched effectively since being called up. But, if the team opts to hold on to Ubaldo, I think Hart will get sent down.Now, for the offense. Hopefully getting back home will allow everyone to get healthy, as Chris Davis, Manny Machado, Matt Wieters, Zach Britton, Buck Showalter and others have battled a virus since the All-Star Game.A lot of clamoring called for Caleb Joseph to be sent down, but let\xe2\x80\x99s face it, we all know he can hit better than he has so far.\xc2\xa0 He is better than a .188 hitter, although he may be the kind of guy who needs regular playing time.\xc2\xa0 In that way, maybe having Pena in the majors would be more effective. But, I\xe2\x80\x99m keeping him as the backup catcher.\xc2\xa0More from The Baltimore WireBaltimore Orioles vs. Kansas City Royals: 4 things to watch8h agoBaltimore Orioles sign first baseman/outfielder Adam Walker1 d agoBaltimore Orioles: Late-inning bullpen options in Minor Leagues1 d agoBaltimore Orioles: Could Logan Verrett be a starter?1 d agoNBA playoffs: Wizards vs. Celtics Game 5: Live stream, odds and more2d agoThe infield is what it is, with the starters and Ryan Flaherty as the backup.But, the outfield is where a shakeup could be in order.In bringing up Julio Borbon Jr., the O\xe2\x80\x99s have a player that is the opposite of what most on the team do. Borbon has speed, is a strong defender, and can also execute the fundamentals.That could put Nolan Reimold\xe2\x80\x98s roster spot in jeopardy.Nolan has struggled since being forced into duty with the Kim injury, and also has a couple base-running gaffes to his credit recently.As the O\xe2\x80\x99s head toward the stretch, having a guy who can be a defensive replacement and also a speed option off the bench becomes more and more important, and even more so for the playoffs. More from Baltimore Orioles5/12 - Baltimore Orioles vs. Kansas City Royals: 4 things to watch5/11 - Baltimore Orioles sign first baseman/outfielder Adam Walker5/11 - Baltimore Orioles: Late-inning bullpen options in Minor Leagues5/11 - Baltimore Orioles: Could Logan Verrett be a starter?5/9 - Baltimore Orioles\xe2\x80\x99 Zach Britton to miss 45-60 days with forearm injuryDespite the struggles recently, and falling out of first place in the division, the O\xe2\x80\x99s have a firm grip on a playoff spot.Is having Borbon more important than Reimold? Or, is this all a moot point with DD looking to play \xe2\x80\x98Let\xe2\x80\x99s Make a Deal\xe2\x80\x99 as the July 31 trade deadline approaches.Only time will tell, but the O\xe2\x80\x99s roster should be written with a pencil for the next 10 days. ', 'thebaltimorewire.com')]

[('Baltimore Orioles: Ubaldo Jimenez Trade Discussions', 'Jun 7, 2016; Baltimore, MD, USA; Baltimore Orioles pitcher Ubaldo Jimenez (31) is congratulated by first baseman Chris Davis (19) after being taken out of the game in the fifth inning against the Kansas City Royals at Oriole Park at Camden Yards. The Orioles won 9-1. Mandatory Credit: Evan Habeeb-USA TODAY SportsThe Baltimore Orioles have been reported over the past 24 hours to be in possible trade discussions with the San Diego Padres involving Ubaldo Jimenez.The obvious problem for the Orioles right now is that they are getting zero bang for the buck from the $13 million hole in the rotation. The guy has not seen the pitching mound in two weeks. In other news, the O\xe2\x80\x99s pitching staff has had an ERA under 3.00 since that time. Probably just a coincidence.So why would the Padres want to have the maestro of moving parts? By trading back Melvin Upton and his even larger salary for this year and next, they save a few million dollars. They are also seeking a prospect from the O\xe2\x80\x99s.Without the prospect, I\xe2\x80\x99d do this deal every day and three times on Sunday. With a prospect included? Well, it depends who the prospect is, but I\xe2\x80\x99d work hard to make it happen.Joey Rickard is out four to six weeks, and he is the best backup for Adam Jones and his quirky back. The Orioles also lost their only speed threat in Rickard, though Julio Borbon provides that at this point. But Upton can fly, especially by Baltimore standards. He has swiped 20 bases this year (7th best in MLB), whereas the entire Orioles team has only 13!\xc2\xa0 Consider this: there are 19 players in MLB who have more SBs individually than does the O\xe2\x80\x99s team.Upton is currently batting .259 in 91 games with 16 home runs. He does strike out a good bit, but we\xe2\x80\x99re used to that.So where does Hyun Soo Kim fit with this? Probably at DH with Upton in left field and Trumbo in right. Pedro Alvarez would be the one to lose the most.Thinking longer-term, the Orioles are probably not going to be able to afford to keep Trumbo next year, so this covers for a bit of that loss, while also not having to have Jimenez around again.There is more news this morning of a second discussion with the Padres \xe2\x80\xa6Source: #Orioles pursuing #Padres\xe2\x80\x99 Cashner in addition to Upton. Separate deals.\xe2\x80\x94 Ken Rosenthal (@Ken_Rosenthal) July 23, 2016So how does this fit with the discussion above? Rosenthal says \xe2\x80\xa6Upton deal with #Orioles would be Upton-for-Ubaldo with #Padres also seeking prospect. SD wants two prospects for Cashner, sources say.\xe2\x80\x94 Ken Rosenthal (@Ken_Rosenthal) July 23, 2016Please! NO! No matter how many writers out there say that this is a certain upgrade for the Orioles, the numbers simply do not prove it \xe2\x80\xa6 especially this year. Baltimore needs pitchers who can go deeper into games, right? Well, Andrew Cashner has made 15 starts this year and thrown 73.1 innings \xe2\x80\xa6 less than five innings per start. His ERA is 4.79. Last year it was 4.43.\xc2\xa0 His WHIP number for the two years are 1.425 \xe2\x80\xa6 in San Diego.Indeed, his stats in 2012 and 2013 were very good. If that is the pitcher who would come to Baltimore, then maybe it could be thought about. But for two prospects? More from Baltimore Orioles5/12 - Baltimore Orioles vs. Kansas City Royals: 4 things to watch5/11 - Baltimore Orioles sign first baseman/outfielder Adam Walker5/11 - Baltimore Orioles: Late-inning bullpen options in Minor Leagues5/11 - Baltimore Orioles: Could Logan Verrett be a starter?5/9 - Baltimore Orioles\xe2\x80\x99 Zach Britton to miss 45-60 days with forearm injurySupposedly the Jays are also interested. Let us hope and pray that they get him. This is the best way he could likely help the Orioles for this year and in the future.So \xe2\x80\xa6 Upton for Jimenez and a little bit of something .. make it happen. Cashner for anything?\xe2\x80\xa6 run the other way. These veteran pitcher \xe2\x80\x9cdeals\xe2\x80\x9d tend to not work out, kill the rotation, and create road blocks for rising prospects to get experience and opportunity. ', 'thebaltimorewire.com')]

                    });                 });             }          } })();     Todd Frazier snatched a bat from his locker recently and raised the handle to his head, behind his right ear, wriggling it like a fishing rod about to be cast.\xe2\x80\x9cI used to want to be like Manny Ramirez,\xe2\x80\x9d Frazier, the Chicago White Sox third baseman, said.Then he flipped around to the other side of an imaginary home plate, bent at the waist and dug his feet into the clubhouse carpet, parroting the gritty style of Mo Vaughn. There was one more he wanted to show, snapping back into a right-handed setup, spreading his legs wide and lowering the bat toward his belt buckle with a fearsome scowl: Jay Buhner.Frazier is putting up offensive numbers this season that would rival any of those former sluggers. But Frazier\xe2\x80\x99s own batting stance, while technically sound and often effective, is not nearly as memorable as the ones he enthusiastically mimicked.So it is in baseball today, where personalization at the plate appears headed the way of bullpen cars and scorecards, disappearing from a game that it once spiced. Batting stances used to identify hitters as vividly as their uniform numbers \xe2\x80\x94 and, sometimes, there was a good reason for that. Stan Musial used to be so coiled in the box that fans watching on television saw more of the No. 6 on Musial\xe2\x80\x99s back than of the tan on his face. Continue reading the main story        Advertisement  Continue reading the main story      But in an age of advanced metrics, enhanced video and intensified coaching, the idiosyncrasies have been pretty much ironed out of the game. There is no Musial, and there is no Julio Franco, who aimed his bat at the pitcher from over his head before unwinding with tornadic gusto as the pitch approached. Nor is there a Phil Plantier, who crouched as a terrified Little Leaguer might when facing a fastball up and in.                     Quiz: Name That Batting Stance                              We asked former big leaguers Sean Casey and Cliff Floyd to impersonate their favorite batting stances. Can you match the stance (and swing) to the player?                        And nor is there anyone like Gary Sheffield, arms violently flapping like windshield wipers in a torrential downpour. Or Moises Alou, legs splayed but knees connected as if magnetically paired, a contortion exhibition at each plate appearance.Instead, a conspicuous sameness has befallen the batter\xe2\x80\x99s boxes of the big leagues. The top stars of today\xe2\x80\x99s era take stances that are essentially alike. Hitting experts say that the prevailing stance these days is near the plate, slightly open, hands raised \xe2\x80\x94 a simple, streamlined model of efficiency. Another word for it might be boring, especially when compared with the old lineups that used to burst with individuality.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Indeed, part of baseball\xe2\x80\x99s appealing history can be traced to its diversity in those moments before the pitcher began his windup. Ty Cobb and Honus Wagner separated their hands. Duke Snider held his elbows up to his chin. There was the fidgety left arm of Joe Morgan and the rhythmic motions of Cal Ripken Jr., sliding the bat along his shoulder like the bow of a violin. Rickey Henderson leaned over the plate; Fred McGriff could hardly stand farther from it.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Some stances simply defied explanation. No hitting coach would advise trying to replicate that of the slugger Tony Batista, who hit 41 home runs for the Toronto Blue Jays in 2000 out of a stance that looked more appropriate for the ballet, beginning with his torso turned directly toward the mound and his bat dancing in front of him, tormenting the pitcher as if to say, \xe2\x80\x9cJust try to get it past me.\xe2\x80\x9d  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Ripken cycled through about a dozen disparate stances during his time with the Baltimore Orioles, a habit he developed by riffing on those he admired while growing up.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99d try to copy all of them,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.His varied looks spawned another generation of imitators, including Ian Kinsler, the second baseman for the Detroit Tigers. \xe2\x80\x9cI knew everyone\xe2\x80\x99s stances,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cand in the backyard I would do them all.\xe2\x80\x9dThese days, though, there is less of an instinct for experimentation. Something like \xe2\x80\x9cfeel\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 a quaint notion in today\xe2\x80\x99s game \xe2\x80\x94 is becoming outmoded. Photo       Julio Franco of the Atlanta Braves in 2004. Franco, who earned the American League batting title in 1991, aimed his bat at the pitcher from over his head before he unwound.  Credit             Harry How/Getty Images           \xe2\x80\x9cOur type of hitting was more about feel and touch and timing,\xe2\x80\x9d said Will Clark, a former first baseman for the San Francisco Giants and the Texas Rangers. \xe2\x80\x9cNow, they\xe2\x80\x99re looking at their mechanics.\xe2\x80\x9dJohn Thorn, the official historian of Major League Baseball, said he rued this development.\xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s some flavor lost, all in the name of greater efficiency,\xe2\x80\x9d Thorn said. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd if you\xe2\x80\x99re a baseball fan of a certain age, like myself, you know on the one hand that the game today is better than it\xe2\x80\x99s ever been. Yet it feels worse.\xe2\x80\x9d  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  A Trademark DevelopsIn the game\xe2\x80\x99s nascent years, there was no universally approved batting technique. There were no batting coaches. A defined batter\xe2\x80\x99s box did not appear until 1874. Until 1886, hitters could inform pitchers where they wanted the ball, high or low, and the incoming pitch would dictate their stance. Often, they choked way up, or gripped the bat like an ax handle, hands spread. Some waved the bat in front of their bodies, thereby disrupting the pitcher\xe2\x80\x99s aim.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  \xe2\x80\x9cIt was very much every man to his own,\xe2\x80\x9d said Peter Morris, a baseball researcher. \xe2\x80\x9cThey used often vastly different types of bats, and many often made their own bat. And they used very different stances, too.\xe2\x80\x9d  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Even the gaping stance of Batista had some precedents. In \xe2\x80\x9cA Game of Inches,\xe2\x80\x9d Morris wrote that Cap Anson, whose career began in 1871, had used a similarly wide stance and ample stride. And his stance was only slightly more pronounced than that of Nap Lajoie, the Hall of Fame infielder from the turn of the last century, Morris said.Such quirks continued to define hitters as the game modernized. Stances evolved as pitchers evolved. Hitters once could drop their hands and wind up to swing, because pitchers, while deceptive, were not overpowering.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Babe Ruth and many others in the 1920s and \xe2\x80\x9930s favored a closed stance, their front foot pointed inward, away from the pitcher, partly in an effort to keep from yanking balls into foul territory. As pitching improved, so did the need for hitters to see the ball better: open stances, with the front foot pointed outward, came in vogue.But all the while, players took different approaches. Hank Greenberg kept his bat parallel to the ground. Al Simmons strode backward. Joe DiMaggio spread his stance wide enough to touch each side of the batter\xe2\x80\x99s box with his feet. Continue reading the main story       Photo       Describing Joe DiMaggio\xe2\x80\x99s incredibly wide stance, John Thorn, the official historian of Major League Baseball, said, \xe2\x80\x9cHe was like the Colossus of Rhodes, with ships sailing between his legs.\xe2\x80\x9d  Credit             Associated Press              \xe2\x80\x9cHe was like the Colossus of Rhodes,\xe2\x80\x9d Thorn said, \xe2\x80\x9cwith ships sailing between his legs.\xe2\x80\x9dTed Williams, in his seminal 1971 book, \xe2\x80\x9cThe Science of Hitting,\xe2\x80\x9d wrote that \xe2\x80\x9cfeet and hand position vary more than anything else from player to player because, unlike golf, the baseball swing is not a grooved swing.\xe2\x80\x9d  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  But Williams also offered pointers. He said he spread his legs exactly 27 inches apart, his hands just below shoulder level, his lead foot slightly opened, but his stance generally closed. He believed in a compact setup, with the hands no more than eight inches from the body, which he considered a \xe2\x80\x9cstronger\xe2\x80\x9d position. He kept his bat vertical, which he said helped increase the \xe2\x80\x9cloop\xe2\x80\x9d in his swing, enabling him to put the ball in the air.Williams was ahead of his time. Today\xe2\x80\x99s hitters seem to be following the clinical approach that he laid out. \xe2\x80\x9cEverybody wants to get that Point A to Point B,\xe2\x80\x9d Frazier said. \xe2\x80\x9cA, foot down, to B, hands through.\xe2\x80\x9d  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Compelled to TinkerSean Casey remembers being in spring training with the Cincinnati Reds in 2003 when a familiar voice called from the opposing dugout.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve been in the game 54 years and I\xe2\x80\x99ve seen a lot of stuff,\xe2\x80\x9d yelled Don Zimmer, then the Yankees\xe2\x80\x99 bench coach, \xe2\x80\x9cbut I ain\xe2\x80\x99t never seen this.\xe2\x80\x9dZimmer was so mesmerized by Casey\xe2\x80\x99s stance that he grabbed the Yankees\xe2\x80\x99 manager, Joe Torre, so he could take a look. Somewhat baffled, they watched Casey, a left-handed hitter, methodically lift the leg farthest from the pitcher rather than the one that strides toward him.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  It was not a timing mechanism, Casey, now an analyst for MLB Network, revealed recently. Rather, Casey\xe2\x80\x99s hips used to tighten up. So he raised his left leg up and down in the batter\xe2\x80\x99s box to release his hips, and the motion stuck.Naturally, even fans picked up on Casey\xe2\x80\x99s odd stomp. During a game in Milwaukee, he heard people in the crowd counting in unison how many times he raised his leg.\xe2\x80\x9cIt totally got me off my game,\xe2\x80\x9d Casey said. \xe2\x80\x9cWhen I didn\xe2\x80\x99t do it my next at-bat, people started booing me.\xe2\x80\x9dActually, a lot of distinct batting stances were born from necessity, guided by feel, hardened by superstition. Sheffield\xe2\x80\x99s aggressive yo-yoing of the bat stemmed from a desire to feel the barrel in his hands. Rod Carew crouched so he would not be overpowered by fastballs up in the zone. Jeff Bagwell widened his legs to keep his head level. Photo       Jeff Bagwell of the Houston Astros in 2004. He widened his legs to keep his head level while swinging.  Credit             Ronald Martinez/Getty Images           Ripken tinkered incessantly with his stance, even when things were going well. In the batting cage, if he felt he was pulling off the ball, he would close up. If his swing felt too long, he would flick his hands to keep them from wrapping around his head.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  \xe2\x80\x9cNormal adjustments you would make are if you couldn\xe2\x80\x99t control your body movements,\xe2\x80\x9d Ripken said. \xe2\x80\x9cLike if you\xe2\x80\x99re getting out in front and getting fooled, you\xe2\x80\x99d spread your stance wider.\xe2\x80\x9d  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  In 1996, before the Orioles were to play the Cleveland Indians in an American League division series, Ripken was so excited to hit that he knew he was going to have trouble staying back on the ball. Privacy Policy     \xe2\x80\x9cI decided, as a bold move, I was just going to spread out and put my bat on my shoulder,\xe2\x80\x9d Ripken said. \xe2\x80\x9cI got antsy and I started sliding my bat on my shoulder as I waited.\xe2\x80\x9dHe hit .444 that series. The so-called \xe2\x80\x9cviolin\xe2\x80\x9d stance was born.Cliff Floyd used to hold his hands near his cheek before abruptly dropping them toward his torso as the pitcher delivered. Opponents, he said, would often try quick-pitching him before his hands sank into place. But he learned to thrive with it.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  \xe2\x80\x9cIt got me in a good rhythm every time,\xe2\x80\x9d said Floyd, who, like Casey, is now an analyst for MLB Network.Floyd would marvel at teammates whose stances he could hardly comprehend. Alou, whom he played with in Miami, seemed immobile in his crouch, yet always appeared among the league\xe2\x80\x99s leaders in average. Todd Zeile stood perfectly upright with his bat resting against his collarbone in a pose that Floyd used to describe as \xe2\x80\x9cla-di-da.\xe2\x80\x9dAnd Zeile said he had adopted the look of his stance from the former first baseman Steve Garvey.\xe2\x80\x9cI started with that in youth baseball, and it developed pretty much into the stance I used all my life,\xe2\x80\x9d said Zeile, who now works for the SNY network.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Franco, with that bat extended over his head, always seemed the most outrageous of all.\xe2\x80\x9cI used to say to him, \xe2\x80\x98If you can hit like that, anybody can hit,\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d said Floyd, who played with Franco with the Mets.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  And yet, Floyd emphasized, the stance, no matter how unusual, does not really matter in terms of success and failure.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  \xe2\x80\x9cAll I care about is when you get ready to hit, the bat head needs to be in a position to stay flat through the zone,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  His point was echoed by Alex Buccilli, who was an outfielder for Coastal Carolina University from 2011 to 2013 and who earned internet fame for what some considered the weirdest stance in baseball history \xe2\x80\x94 an open-legged, backward-leaning, crouching, arms-raised position that looked as uncomfortable as it did unconventional.Now a hitting instructor in Myrtle Beach, S.C., Buccilli pointed out that his crazy stance was just a starting point, one that enabled his body to move into a consistent hitting position every time.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  \xe2\x80\x9cA stance is personal,\xe2\x80\x9d Buccilli said, adding, \xe2\x80\x9cYou can stand on your head for all I care, as long as you get to the same position after that.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x98Not By Feel\xe2\x80\x99 Photo       The Rays\xe2\x80\x99 Brad Miller waiting for a pitch with one hand on the bat and the other low at his side during a game against Oakland on Thursday.  Credit             Ben Margot/Associated Press           Gar Ryness has fashioned a career out of imitating famous hitters. If anybody has a vested interest in the future of batting stances, it would be Ryness, the Batting Stance Guy, YouTube phenomenon, author, speaker, entertainer and faithful practitioner of what he calls \xe2\x80\x9cthe least marketable skill in America\xe2\x80\x9d: imitating batting stances.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Ryness argues that there are absolutely bizarre stances still alive in today\xe2\x80\x99s game, though he acknowledged that they might be harder to find. He cited Brad Miller, the starting shortstop for the Tampa Bay Rays, who stands at the plate with one hand gripping the bat while the other hangs limp at his side until the pitch approaches.\xe2\x80\x9cHe does the craziest thing I have seen in a batter\xe2\x80\x99s box in 30 years,\xe2\x80\x9d Ryness said. \xe2\x80\x9cHe stands there like Pete Gray,\xe2\x80\x9d a one-armed St. Louis Browns player from the 1940s.There are others: John Jaso, a Pittsburgh infielder, stands with both feet treading the back line of the box; San Francisco\xe2\x80\x99s Denard Span curls his front toe back toward the catcher; Cleveland\xe2\x80\x99s Jason Kipnis points his barrel at the umpire; the Cubs\xe2\x80\x99 Ben Zobrist pulsates his hands as if shaking the stubborn last drops from a ketchup bottle.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  But because the megawatt sluggers of the current era \xe2\x80\x94 like Mike Trout, Bryce Harper, Giancarlo Stanton or Nolan Arenado \xe2\x80\x94 all use relatively straightforward stances, the others tend to get overlooked.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Thorn compared the waning of unique stances to what he sees on the pitcher\xe2\x80\x99s mound, as windups and deliveries get simplified and more efficient, though that is most likely the result of an effort to reduce arm injuries. Continue reading the main story       Photo       The Cardinals\xe2\x80\x99 Hall of Famer Stan Musial in 1952. His distinctive stance was, unlike that of his contemporary Joe DiMaggio, very tightly coiled.  Credit             Francis Miller/The LIFE Picture Collection, via Getty Images              For hitters, other factors are in play. Curtis Granderson, an outfielder for the Mets, said he had begun his career with a wide stance \xe2\x80\x94 \xe2\x80\x9cI thought it looked cool\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 and restless hands that he had picked up by watching Buhner. But over time, hitting coaches have trimmed away at the excess motion.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  \xe2\x80\x9cGuys are trying to get simpler, rather than having so many moving parts before they get to where they need to go,\xe2\x80\x9d Casey said. \xe2\x80\x9cThe video proves it.\xe2\x80\x9d  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Kinsler said: \xe2\x80\x9cEverything is so technical now because of the influence of video. You look at kids in golf, and all the kids look the same \xe2\x80\x94 they\xe2\x80\x99re like robots. Nobody swings like Jim Furyk or Jack Nicklaus.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x99Some believe the increased velocity of pitches today is another factor, contributing to a desire by players to be hyperprepared to hit the fastball.\xe2\x80\x9cSo many coaches are saying, \xe2\x80\x98Simpler the better,\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d Floyd said. \xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98As easy as you can keep it so you can hit the fastball.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9dRipken, however, pointed out that Sheffield was one of the best fastball hitters in the game, even though his bat was pointing at the pitcher as he lifted his leg.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Ripken said he thought the explanation for all the current sameness lay in the fact that hitters were taking more batting practice than they used to and were carefully honing an ideal swing out of an ideal stance.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  \xe2\x80\x9cI think the routines and the particularness of video has really changed,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cThe way that they search for answers is visually, and not by feel.\xe2\x80\x9dFrazier lamented the lack of creativity in today\xe2\x80\x99s batter\xe2\x80\x99s box. In the clubhouse that day in the Bronx, he imitated Sheffield, Craig Counsell and Danny Tartabull. If he were left-handed, he insisted, he would hit like Vaughn once did.\xe2\x80\x9cI wish I played with all those guys,\xe2\x80\x9d Frazier said. \xe2\x80\x9cIt would have been awesome.\xe2\x80\x9dIt happened to be Play Ball Weekend at Yankee Stadium, and Frazier hustled off to greet local Little League teams. The young ballplayers watched Frazier go 2 for 4 out of a stance that was as efficient and unremarkable as the baselines on the field.  A version of this article appears in print on July 24, 2016, on Page SP1 of the New York edition with the headline: In the Box, No More Thinking Outside It. ', 'www.nytimes.com'), ("Indians' miscue helps Orioles complete sweep with 5-3 win", 'Cleveland Indians pitcher Corey Kluber throws against the Baltimore Orioles in the first inning of a baseball game, Sunday, July 24, 2016, in Baltimore. (AP Photo/Gail Burton)(Photo: The Associated Press)CONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMOREBALTIMORE (AP) \xe2\x80\x94 There was something fundamentally wrong with the Cleveland Indians\' performance in a 5-3 loss to the Baltimore Orioles.A botched throw by catcher Roberto Perez enabled Pedro Alvarez to reach after a ninth-inning strikeout, and Nolan Reimold followed with a two-out homer to give the Orioles a three-game sweep of the AL Central leaders.Cleveland reliever Cody Allen (2-4) began the ninth by striking out Alvarez, but the ball eluded Perez. After fielding the bouncing ball off the backstop, Perez hit Alvarez in the helmet with the throw for an error.The Indians\' catchers often practice the throw to first after a dropped third strike, but Perez still evidently has some work to do."I don\'t think he rushed. He didn\'t move his feet," manager Terry Francona said. "We talk to him about that all the time. You don\'t want somebody to learn a lesson the hard way, and he did."A sacrifice bunt and a strikeout followed before Reimold lined a 2-0 pitch into the left-field seats."I was taking the first pitch, trying to get comfortable," Reimold said. "After that, I got up 2-0 and I was ready to hit. I figured he would try to throw a fastball there."Activated from the disabled list before the game, Darren O\'Day (7-1) struck out the side in the ninth.Cleveland lost the season series to AL East-leading Baltimore 5-1 after being outscored 15-6 in these three games at Camden Yards."Every time you go anywhere and get swept it\'s not a good thing," second baseman Jason Kipnis said. "This was a closer ballgame, more what we expected how we should be playing. We put up a battle there."Filling a void at the end of the Baltimore rotation, Vance Worley allowed two runs and five hits in seven innings. Making his fourth start, the right-hander retired the final 11 batters he faced in his longest outing since September 2014, with Pittsburgh against Milwaukee.Worley left with a 3-2 lead, but All-Star reliever Brad Brach promptly allowed an unearned run in the eighth. After Jonathan Schoop fumbled a grounder to second base, Mike Napoli snapped an 0-for-11 skid with an RBI single.Cleveland starter Corey Kluber gave up three runs and six hits in seven innings. He struck out eight,The Indians went up 2-0 in the fourth on an RBI double by Tyler Naquin and a sacrifice fly by Perez, who earlier got his first hit in 17 at-bats this season.Baltimore tied it in the bottom half, courtesy of an overturned call following a challenge by the Orioles. After Manny Machado singled in a run, Alvarez hit into an apparent inning-ending double play with runners on the corners. But he earned an RBI after a replay review showed he was safe at first base.After hitting a double and scoring Baltimore\'s first run in the fourth inning, Schoop delivered a solo shot in the fifth for a 3-2 lead. It was his career-high 17th home run, eclipsing the 16 he hit in 2014.BALL THREE, NOT FOURMachado was picked off first base in the eighth inning after Chris Davis took a pitch outside the strike zone, dropped his bat and headed from the batter\'s box. Davis thought it was ball four, but the count actually moved to 3-2. Machado was swayed by his teammate\'s action and strayed off the base before being thrown out by Perez.TRAINER\'S ROOMIndians: 3B Juan Uribe returned to the starting lineup for the first time since being hit in the head with a pitch on Friday night.Orioles: OF Hyun Soo Kim (hamstring) began a two-day rehabilitative assignment with Double-A Bowie. If all goes well, he will be activated from the DL on Tuesday. ... C Matt Wieters missed a sixth straight game with a foot injury. ... The wife of Ubaldo Jimenez had a baby. He went on paternity leave Saturday and will likely use all three days.UP NEXTIndians: Cleveland gets Monday off before opening a two-game interleague series at home against the Washington Nationals.Orioles: Yovani Gallardo (3-2, 5.69 ERA) takes on the visiting Colorado Rockies in the opener of a three-game series Monday night.CONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORECopyright 2016 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed. ', 'www.usatoday.com')]

[('Orioles Trade Targets: Melvin Upton Jr. and Andrew Cashner ...', ' The trade deadline is upon us and we need to brace ourselves, the unnamed sources are coming. The heaviest and hottest Orioles rumors so far have been for two San Diego Padres, Melvin Upton Jr. and Andrew Cashner.     Both are flawed and both have their own upside. Remember though, as our fearless leader loves to say, the first rule of baseball rumors is that nothing will probably happen. So, let\xe2\x80\x99s get into me writing thousands of words about moves that probably won\xe2\x80\x99t happen.  Melvin Upton Jr.  Orioles fan know Melvin from back when he went by B.J. Upton. He played on the Tampa Bay Rays for at least parts of eight seasons. He has primarily played left field for the Padres this season. He is a right  handed hitter and will turn 32 years old later this year. He is currently hitting .256/.304/.439 posting a 101 wRC+. He is owed around $7.5 million for the rest of 2016 and will be owed $16.4 million in 2017.  Upton had a bit of resurgence last season at the plate posting a 110 wRC+ for the year. He signed his big contract with the Braves after the 2012 season and was atrocious.     While in Atlanta his plate discipline eroded as did his contact skills and power. He went from an above average major leauger to below replacement level. While in San Diego, his power has reemerged and while he is still struggling to make contact, his power numbers have kept him above water.     Upton can help the current Orioles roster in three ways. First, he is an excellent base runner which the Orioles sorely lack. He has 20 stolen bases which would be seven more than the entire Orioles team. He also is an above average bases runner all around\xe2\x80\x94he has accumulated 4.2 base running runs (you can read more about that here) which would put him second on the team behind of all people Chris Davis (it\xe2\x80\x99s not all about speed). Second, Upton is an above average defender. The Orioles outfield defense is atrocious. It is the 29th ranked outfield defense according to UZR. The easiest way for the Orioles to improve their run prevention would be to improve their outfield defense.     Upton has been an above average left fielder his entire career. His overall defensive numbers are not pretty this season, but that is mostly due to a poor small sample size of 80 innings in center field. He is still an above average defender on the corners. Three, he hits for power and can hit lefties. So far in 2016, his walk rate has fallen to a career low 6.1 percent, not a great sign. However, he has a .183 isolated power number and already has 16 home runs and 11 doubles.  The Orioles have a plethora of low on base/high slugging hitter, but this isn\xe2\x80\x99t necessarily a bad thing for the offense adding even more fire power to the bottom of the order.     Furthermore, he hits lefties. He has a career 110 wRC+ against left handed pitching and has posted a 146 wRC+ in 2016. The Orioles could use some help against lefties. As a team they have posted a 88 wRC+ against left handed pitching this year which is tied for 25th in the league with the Rockies.  Upton is a flawed, but useful player that \x7fI believe can help the Orioles, the only question after that is what the cost will be to acquire him. The rumored deal is Upton for Ubaldo Jimenez and a \xe2\x80\x9cprospect.\xe2\x80\x9d I love a good \xe2\x80\x9cbad contract swap\xe2\x80\x9d trade.  For the Padres, this saves them some money, gives them a reclamation project they can possibly flip next season, and a lottery ticket.  For the Orioles, it gives them not what they\xe2\x80\x99re looking for\xe2\x80\x94a starting pitcher\xe2\x80\x94but it helps them in areas that can be easily improved. It will cost them about $5 million more over the course of the next season and a half and the \xe2\x80\x9cprospect.\xe2\x80\x9d  The only so called prospect the Orioles should not be giving away is Chance Sisco, otherwise I am not tied to any of them. Maybe Jomar Reyes, but otherwise the whole lot are tradeable assets. Giving up much of value for Upton is foolhardy. He is not a great player, but a useful one. He also doesn\xe2\x80\x99t come cheap.     The name being floated is Tanner Scott. A flame throwing lefty reliever just promoted to AA Bowie with severe command and control problems. If the deal was Jimenez and Scott for Upton, I\xe2\x80\x99d do it. Anyone much better then Scott, I\xe2\x80\x99d have to think about it.  Andrew Cashner The other Padre the Orioles have been rumored to be after is Andrew Cashner. He is set to be a free agent, so this would be a rental deal. He is a right handed starting pitcher who has struggled the last two seasons. His ERA currently sits at 4.79 the worst mark since his rookie year.  While he struggled last year results wise pitching to a 4.34 ERA, his peripherals were still alright in 2015. He was essentially a league average pitcher who threw 180 innings, which the Orioles could use. However, in 2016 the peripheral statistics have nose dived as well.  He currently has his highest walk rate since 2012 and the lowest whiff rate of his career. Not to mention that hitters are making contact on his pitches at a career high rate as well even though they are swinging less overall at those pitches.  On top of all that, Cashner has been giving up the gopher ball at a 14.7 percent home run to fly ball rate. The highest rate he has given up home runs at since 2012.    Cashner had good results last in 2013 and 2014 for the Padres. He was able to run a low BABIP and a low HR/FB rate. Whether or not that was due to luck or skill is up to you, but for the last two years and especially in 2016 he has been the same pitcher.  A lot of teams are in on the Cashner sweepstakes at this point. On top of the Orioles, the Giants, Tigers, Rangers, Marlins, and Astros have all been connected to Cashner. The reported asking price from the Orioles is \xe2\x80\x9ctwo prospects.\xe2\x80\x9d  Ah, there are those magical words again. For a half season rental of a soon to be 30 year old right handed pitcher the price cannot be all that high. However, if the Orioles are competing with that many teams, they will quickly be outmatched in terms of buying power.  I am a little hazy on why Cashner is so desirable. His three most predominate traits are that he has an arm attached to his torso, that arm can throw the ball sixty feet six inches, and he is currently breathing. He hasn\xe2\x80\x99t gotten good results since 2014 and those results are dubious.  Cashner isn\xe2\x80\x99t even an innings eater as he never thrown above 200 innings in a year and has only gone over 175 innings once. The Orioles could use all the help they could get in the rotation and if the price is low enough then Cashner makes some sense, but I am not convinced he is worth getting into a bidding war over.     \t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t*** The Orioles are in first place and are looking to add, with a weakened farm system they are going to have to get creative. I would bet on the Orioles making at least one trade before the July 31st non-waiver trade deadline and at least one more before the August 31st waiver trade deadline.  Whether or not it is for either of Upton or Cashner remains to be seen. Either way, it\xe2\x80\x99s shaping up to be a fun stretch run in Baltimore. Tune in on 105.7 the Fan (no streaming).\xc2\xa0 \xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94-  When: 7:05 PM\xc2\xa0ET,\xc2\xa0Monday, July 25, 2016 Where: Oriole Park at Camden Yards, Baltimore, Maryland TV: 7:05 p.m. ET \xc2\xa0MASN (Baltimore)   By SportsDirect Inc. The Baltimore Orioles are winners of four straight and have retaken the lead in the American League East. The Orioles, who host the Colorado Rockies on Monday in the opener of a three-game interleague series, seemed to turn their biggest weakness into a strength as the pitching staff came through over the last four games. Baltimore is last in the AL with 37 quality starts but recorded three of those in the last four contests, the lone exception coming when Dylan Bundy did not allow an earned run in five innings on Friday. The Orioles are 36-14 at home after allowing a total of six runs in a three-game sweep of the AL Central-leading Cleveland Indians over the weekend, capped by Nolan Reimold\xe2\x80\x99s walk-off home run on Sunday. That Baltimore staff will have to deal with streaking rookie shortstop Trevor Story, who piled up four homers and nine RBIs in a three-game sweep of the Atlanta Braves over the weekend and has six blasts in the last seven games to increase his National League-leading total to 27. Story is three home runs shy of tying Nomar Garciaparra for the rookie record of 30 homers by a shortstop. PITCHING MATCHUP: Rockies LH Jorge De La Rosa (6-7, 6.07 ERA) vs. Orioles RH Yovani Gallardo (3-2, 5.69) De La Rosa had a string of five straight quality starts come to an abrupt end when he was crushed in an interleague start against the Tampa Bay Rays on Wednesday. The Mexico native was ripped for nine runs \xe2\x80\x93 seven earned \xe2\x80\x93 on 11 hits and a pair of walks in four innings. De La Rosa fared better in his previous start against AL East competition, limiting the New York Yankees to three hits in five scoreless innings on June 14. Gallardo has gone four consecutive turns without a quality start but at least worked deeper into the game when he served up four runs in seven innings at the Yankees on Wednesday. The fellow Mexican issued 15 walks in 21 innings over those four turns and is allowing opponents a .296 batting average. Gallardo spent his first eight seasons in the NL and never managed to beat Colorado, posting a 0-5 record with a 6.08 ERA in 10 games \xe2\x80\x93 nine starts. WALK-OFFS 1. Orioles C Matt Wieters (foot) missed the last six games and is day-to-day. 2. Colorado\xe2\x80\x99s top OF prospect, 22-year-old David Dahl, is expected to join the team on Monday and make his major league debut in the series. 3. Baltimore 1B Chris Davis is 0-for-18 with eight strikeouts in his last five games. PREDICTION: Orioles 10, Rockies 8  var addthis_product = \'wpp-261\'; var addthis_config = {"data_track_clickback":true};if (typeof(addthis_share) == "undefined"){ addthis_share = {"url_transforms":{"shorten":{"twitter":"bitly"}},"shorteners":{"bitly":{"login":"cbslocal","apiKey":"R_bfe2742f79bb4091b0fcfbdf5c6a81ca"}}};}  ', 'baltimore.cbslocal.com'), ('Baltimore Orioles: Can Improved Pitching Continue?', 'The Baltimore Orioles have benefitted from improved pitching over the past two weeks. Could this continue throughout the remainder of the season?It has been largely assumed for some time that the Orioles\xe2\x80\x99 only chance to make the playoffs, win the division, or compete well into October was dependent upon getting at least one veteran arm for the rotation. But as we have written here on The Baltimore Wire ad infinitum, making this happen successfully is not only expensive long-term, it is fraught with historic disappointment in the product. I\xe2\x80\x99d sooner predict a cheerful, peaceful presidential campaign season than predict success from any pitching acquisition.If the O\xe2\x80\x99s pitching staff can continue as they have over the past 12 games (8-4 with a 2.77 ERA), the Birds really don\xe2\x80\x99t need to be making any moves. But that is asking for and hoping for a lot \xe2\x80\xa6 probably too much. We could be happy with a 3.50 ERA, or something like that!The question is essentially whether the staff, particularly the starting rotation, has finally arrived at what we hoped they could be, or whether the previous period of struggle is the real \xe2\x80\x9cthem\xe2\x80\x9d and that this new success is the aberration.To answer the question posed by this piece, yes, the Orioles\xe2\x80\x99 pitching is capable of continued high-level success. The talent is there, both from the history of veterans and the rising skills of young pitchers. But the devil is always in the details of execution of talent on the field, specifically over that space of 60\xe2\x80\x996\xe2\x80\x9d.It is reasonable to expect Chris Tillman to extend his good season through the end. Kevin Gausman has pitched better than his record, and we can hope he is finally arriving into a regular and dependable piece for every fifth day.Dylan Bundy looks to have \xe2\x80\x9carrived\xe2\x80\x9d also in terms of pitching ability. It was great to see back-to-back wins from Gausman and him \xe2\x80\xa6 been waiting a few years to experience that!\xc2\xa0 The issue, of course, relates to how many innings are safely available in his arm. This is an imprecise science, though I wonder if the physique and strength for which he is renowned might not position him for a higher number than is typically true of TJ-recovering pitchers.The following two pieces are the wild cards for sure: Yovani Gallardo and Vance Worley. Both have the veteran ability to work the edges and pitch out of trouble while minimizing damage. They can both get shelled from time to time as well. Like Miguel Gonzalez before them, they have to be very good at walking a fine line. It would be huge if they could do it.It is not inconceivable that Mike Wright or Tyler Wilson could put together a hot stretch and contribute well. It too would be huge! The more likely of the two is Wilson. After a 5.22 ERA in 13 starts and 16 games over 81 innings with the Orioles, he has been sent down for a sort of \xe2\x80\x9cre-set\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cre-start.\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0 The numbers are too ugly to print, though he reports feeling good, for what that\xe2\x80\x99s worth. But this is the guy who shut out the Red Sox over eight innings on June 16th.Mike Wright has had a strange season. His 2.58 ERA at AAA Norfolk is half of the 5.97 for the Orioles. We know that there is a jump from one level to the other, but not that much of a difference. And his last three starts for Norfolk have him with a combined ERA of 4.58 over 17.2 innings. Yet again, we know that talent is there, but not the consistency.Left out of this discussion so far has been Ubaldo Jimenez. And \xe2\x80\x9cleft out\xe2\x80\x9d is what he needs to continue to be. The Orioles have simply not had need of a mop-up man lately. In the 10 games since the All-Star break, the O\xe2\x80\x99s have only scored 29 runs \xe2\x80\xa6 yes, let that sink in. They have given up 30, so being 6-4 ain\xe2\x80\x99t bad. But there have been no blowout wins or losses, so no need for a \xe2\x80\x9cjust-git-r-done-and-go-home\xe2\x80\x9d pitcher. I think I\xe2\x80\x99ve written in the past how I have a car I have nicknamed \xe2\x80\x9cUbaldo,\xe2\x80\x9d since it was very expensive and does not work as advertised.All of this discussion so far has been about starting pitchers. What is there to say about the bullpen other than that they have been a great team strength?\xc2\xa0 And now Darren O\xe2\x80\x99Day is back. A key element of the pen will be how they handle middle innings, particularly in Bundy starts, along with any others who can\xe2\x80\x99t get through six innings.While we are talking about pitching, let\xe2\x80\x99s weigh in for a moment on the trade of Aroldis Chapman from the Yankees to the Cubs for four prospects. In the short term this is good for the Orioles, who have nine games remaining with the Evil Empire, including six in NY. It is also good that the Nationals did not get him, since the O\xe2\x80\x99s have their four games yet with Washington. From a baseball perspective, it would be better to see Papelbon at the end of a game, though it is never a good thing to see or be around Papelbon in any context. In the longer term, it will be interesting to see what comes of the prospects who now are with the Yankees.
